title: Summers Says: Markets Will Survive Reddit Traders
text: Jan.22 -- Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, a Wall Street Week contributor, says markets will survive the actions of Reddit-charged day traders, but regulations need to be more modern.

title: There Are Micro Bubbles in the Market: Sonders
text: Jan.22 -- Charles Schwab Chief Investment Strategist Liz Ann Sonders says she sees micro bubbles in the market. She says that the froth coming from the retail investors piling into low-priced stocks is different from the bubble on the late 1990s to 2000s.

text: Netflix, Apple, and the rest of the FAANGs helped lift the stock market this past week. What investors need to know.

text: "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer looks ahead to next week's Wall Street developments, which includes Apple's latest quarterly earnings report.

title: The Smallest Bit Of Empathy For The Swollen Herd
text: Unemployment aid isn't supposed to be permanent, however, since recoveries are believed to just happen; organic and symmetrical. Payments had to be extended because, for one big reason, the job-cutting didn't actually end until almost a year after the Great "Recession" was "officially" declared ended.

title: The Dow Fell 179 Points Because Fauci Warned About Covid Mutations
text: Coronavirus vaccinations look less effective against new strains, Dr. Anthony Fauci warned before the market opened. Stocks never had a chance.

title: VC partner Mercedes Bent on retail investing themes in 2021
text: Mercedes Bent, Lightspeed Venture Partners, joins 'Closing Bell' to talk about millennial investing themes and how brands are tapping into what users are looking for when they invest in companies.

title: Stock Market Today: Nasdaq Scratches Out Another Record Finish
text: The Nasdaq came out of a mixed day with yet another fresh high. More interesting were Friday's moves by IBM, Intel and GameStop.

title: Victoria Fernandez warns there may be pullback in US equities
text: Victoria Fernandez, Crossmark global investments chief market strategist, says uncertainty on whether the $1.9 trillion coronavirus plan may pass in Congress may create some consolidation and pullback in U.S. equities. She joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss.

title: How Biden's Stimulus Plan Could Impact Municipal Bonds
text: Jan.22 -- Nick Venditti, Wells Fargo Asset Management senior portfolio manager, discusses what the Biden administration's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan means for the municipal bond market. He speaks with Bloomberg's Taylor Riggs on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: Loomis Sayles Vice Chair Fuss on Inflation, Credit Market
text: Jan.22 -- Loomis Sayles & Co. Vice Chairman Dan Fuss discusses the outlook for U.S. inflation and the credit market with Bloomberg's Vonnie Quinn on "Bloomberg Markets."

title: Biden wields executive power to tackle U.S. pandemic economic crisis
text: U.S. President Joe Biden on Friday ordered the faster issuance of pandemic stimulus checks to needy families and increased food aid for children who normally rely on school meals, an effort to ease Americans' burdens while Congress negotiates over his proposed $1.9 trillion economic stimulus package.

title: Biden: If we act now our economy will be better, stronger
text: President Joe Biden announced he's signing two new executive orders to address the economic crisis. His orders include boosting food assistance, SNAP allotments, allowing workers to forgo working in unsafe workplaces, and increasing the minimum wage to $15 dollars.

title: Nasdaq sets new record as stocks hold onto weekly gains
text: Stocks ended mixed on Friday, but managed to cling to weekly gains as investors eyed the economic impact of COVID-19 restrictions in Europe. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 3,841.

title: Jeremy Siegel expects higher inflation, which will hurt bond holders
text: Jeremy Siegel, Wharton finance professor, says the Fed has poured a tremendous amount of money into the economy in response to the pandemic, which will eventually cause higher inflation and hurt bond holders. David Rosenberg of Rosenberg Research joins discussion on whether there will be higher inflation in 2021.

title: S&P 500 falls for the first time this week as US stocks edge lower
text: US equities fell on Friday after closing at all-time highs, as investors weighed the outlook for Biden's nearly $2 trillion stimulus bill and grew concerned amid reports the new coronavirus strain may be deadlier. The S&P 500 fell for the first time this week.  There is some evidence the new variant of the coronavirus first identified in the UK may be up to 30% more deadly than previous variants, the UK government has said.

title: The Major Equity Averages Reached Risky Levels. Here's What You Need To Know.
text: The major equity averages set all-time highs between January 14 and January 21

title: Q4 and 2021 Earnings Estimates Keep Going Up
text: We are off to a great start in the Q4 earnings season, with a historically high proportion of the reporting companies not only beating consensus EPS and revenue estimates, but also providing positive and reassuring guidance and commentary about the current and coming periods. This is helping sustain the positive revisions trend that has been in place since July 2020, as the chart below shows.

title: China Stock Bans: What Investors Need To Know
text: After some back and forth, three Chinese state-owned companies were booted off the New York Stock Exchange on Jan. 11 based on an executive order signed by President Donald Trump last November. KraneShares CIO Brendan Ahern breaks down the latest news and what investors need to know about the China stock bans.

title: Key Words: Stock-market legend sees few weeks of ‘putting your last, desperate chips into the game'—then pop
text: In an interview with Bloomberg TV's “Front Row,” the storied investor, Jeremy Grantham, who is often credited with several prescient market calls over the past two decades, insists that a steady rise in stocks, fostered by free money from the Federal Reserve and the government can't continue without consequences.

title: Time Preference, Interest Rates, And Stagflation
text: The central bank influences the short-term interest rates by influencing monetary liquidity in the markets. Increases in real wealth tend to lower individuals' time preferences whereas decreases in real wealth tend to raise them.

title: Inauguration Week Marked by Record Highs
text: Coming off last week's losses, it has been a positive holiday-shortened week for the major indexes.

title: The 100 Things I've Learned in Investing
text: Please learn from my mistakes!

title: Home sales hit 14-year high in 2020, pushing prices to record levels
text: Last year brought skyrocketing unemployment and a global pandemic that battered the economy, but people were still buying homes. Existing home sales in 2020 rose to the highest level in 14 years as prices climbed to a record high.

title: Federal Reserve Watch: Fed Keeps Things Steady
text: The Federal Reserve continues to purchase open-market securities outright as it attempts to support the economic recovery and get inflation moving at a faster rate. Through its actions over the past year, there seems to be plenty of liquidity in the banking sector and in the corporate sector, keeping short-term interest rates low.

title: In One Chart: Junk bonds off to record start in 2021 as Goldman sees low chance of higher rates that ‘kill the business cycle'
text: U.S. companies with 'junk,' or below investment-grade ratings, are borrowing in the bond market at a record clip to start 2021, defying concerns that trillions worth of pandemic aid for the economy could lead to higher borrowing costs that end the business cycle.

title: Wall Street can relax, moderates have the mandate
text: Stocks have surged since Election Day and are near record highs. Wall Street is clearly a fan of President Joe Biden's new administration -- and it's largely because of growing hope that moderates in both parties will continue to call the shots.

title: Tech shares could retake market reins as earnings heat up
text: A bevy of major U.S. earnings reports next week led by Apple, Microsoft and Facebook could help technology and growth stocks reassert their dominance after a recent run by banks, energy and other potential beneficiaries of an economic reopening.

title: Fund Flows Show Lack of Market Froth, BNP's Morris Says

title: Grantham Sees Bubble Signal in Huge Penny-Stock Volumes
text: Jan.22 -- Jeremy Grantham, co-founder and chief investment strategist of Boston's GMO, points to the trillions of shares traded in penny stocks as the kind of “crazy behavior” indicative of a bubble top in the equity market. He also discusses investors' misplaced faith in monetary stimulus.

title: US business activity picks up as manufacturing gauge hits record high, IHS Markit says
text: A key gauge of US business activity swung higher this month as strong demand lifted manufacturers and service businesses alike. IHS Markit's composite output index climbed to 58 from 55.3 in an early January reading, hitting its highest level in two months. The firm's index of service-industry business activity improved to 57.5 from 54.8, while its purchasing managers' index for manufacturers leaped to a record high of 59.1 from 57.1.

title: The stock market is in a bubble that is being fueled by the policies out of DC, BofA warns
text: The stock market is in a bubble that is being fueled by the policies out of Washington D.C., Bank of America said in a note on Friday. "DC's policy bubble [is] fueling Wall St's asset bubble," BofA said, adding that a rise in inflation and interest rates could be on the horizon.

title: Grantham Says Stock Prices Reveal Folly of Fed Policy
text: Jan.22 -- GMO co-founder and Chief Investment Strategist Jeremy Grantham criticizes the Federal Reserve for pursuing policies that produced a state of “mild hysteria” in stocks, not the hoped-for improvements in economic output and productivity. He spoke exclusively to Erik Schatzker on Bloomberg's “Front Row.

title: Biden to sign executive order on COVID-19 relief
text: President Joe Biden will sign two executive orders Friday, one on COVID-19 relief and another on workers' protections. #FoxBusiness Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: 2020 Was a Rough Year for Short Sellers
text: As stocks rose on retail investor-fueled euphoria, short sellers faced with mounting losses and high borrowing fees were forced to close their positions and buy.

title: Stocks Ignore Tax Hikes That Are Likely After Pandemic Ends
text: Higher levies on corporate earnings and investors' dividends and capital gains could be in the mix, along with curbs on share buybacks.
